etymologies: late Middle English: from medieval Latin perquisitum ‘acquisition’, from Latin perquirere ‘search diligently for’, from per- ‘thoroughly’ + quaerere ‘seek’

notes.text: Perquisite and prerequisite are sometimes confused. Perquisite usually means ‘an extra allowance or privilege’: he had all the perquisites of a movie star, including a stand-in. Prerequisite means ‘something required as a condition’: passing the examination was one of the prerequisites for a teaching position

definitions: a thing regarded as a special right or privilege enjoyed as a result of one's position

examples.text: the wife of a president has all the perquisites of stardom

shortDefinitions: thing regarded as special right or privilege enjoyed as result of one's position

definitions: a thing that has served its primary use and is then given to a subordinate or employee as a customary right.
